p: Tuberculosis, also likely transmitted to humans by cattle, is among the oldest and most persistent of human pathogens. As with SARS-CoV-2, it is spread via respiratory secretions, with prominent fever, cough, and shortness of breath, but the tempo of symptoms and disease and its management is far more prolonged. An estimated 25–30% of the global population (1.7–2 billion people) is infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis [ 5]. TB is the ninth leading cause of death globally and has surpassed human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) as the leading cause of death from a communicable disease. Globally, an estimated 10.0 million (9.0–11.1 million) people fell ill, and an estimated 1.5 million died of TB in 2019, despite the existence of effective prevention and treatment [ 6].
